thread.title: Welcome to crazy exercise time with Mikhail Prokhorov
thread.title_full: Welcome to crazy exercise time with Mikhail Prokhorov | New York Post

author: Tim Bontemps
title: Welcome to crazy exercise time with Mikhail Prokhorov
text:
DURHAM, N.C. – The Nets knew Mikhail Prokhorov was coming to practice Wednesday at Duke University.
They didn’t know the owner would be putting them through a workout.
After the Russian billionaire spent the morning watching his team practice, he assembled the players on one of the practice courts and proceeded to demonstrate a variety of martial arts exercises using volleyballs, tennis balls, boards and sticks – then had the players give each of them a try.
“I think my preference was to come personally, and to say hello to the players and to the coaches,” said Prokhorov, who was making his first stateside visit to training camp since buying the team in May 2010. “I think it’s very important for the new team to have special team building, and of course the commitment of ownership as part of the team.
“But I also wanted to share with them my own experience with martial arts, and I really will be happy if it helps them in some way.”
Some of the more peculiar exercises during the half-hour session: doing push-ups while balancing on four volleyballs, doing push-ups on a volleyball with a stick, and bouncing a volleyball off the floor with one hand while bouncing a tennis ball on a board with the other.
Prokhorov doing push-ups on a basketball with a stick 
A video posted by Tim Bontemps (@timbontemps) on Sep 30, 2015 at 9:31am PDT 
The players did their best to keep up, and by the end some were spending time with Prokhorov getting some additional instruction.
“That was cool,” Jarrett Jack said. “It was my first time meeting him in person, but for him to come out and show he’s a guy that actually tries to better himself, health-wise, that’s pretty cool. He’s works in a different realm, definitely, than we usually do.
“It was clear to see that it looks like it’s easy, but it definitely isn’t. It’s clear he’s put some time in, and he’s competitive, too.”
Prokhorov dribbling against the wall, part one 
A video posted by Tim Bontemps (@timbontemps) on Sep 30, 2015 at 9:33am PDT 
Prokhorov made it clear he wasn’t trying to show anyone up, just to show them some things he hoped could help them in the future.
“All of [the players] are great partners,” Prokhorov said. “It’s only the first try. Imagine how I would look playing basketball? I would be clumsy. They are great athletes.”
The players aren't quite as good: 
A video posted by Tim Bontemps (@timbontemps) on Sep 30, 2015 at 9:19am PDT 
It also was a rare chance for the players and coaches to spend one-on-one time with the owner, who pops in and out of town for games, often without seeing any of them.
“It’s always nice to be around him,” Lionel Hollins said. “It’s my second time in person talking to him. It’s nice to get to know him, for him to get to know me.
“He’s a very interesting guy. He should probably doing that [Dos Equis] commercial, ‘I don’t normally drink beer, but when I do… .’ He’s one of those guys that’s been around the world, has a varied sort of interest, and it’s interesting to get to know him better.”
  brooklyn nets ,  jarrett jack ,  lionel hollins ,  mikhail prokhorov
